context: Ethyl acetate was detected only in a few samples obtained with S. cerevisiae “Southern” strains and only in sample 1 obtained with a “Northern” yeast (Table 1). These S. cerevisiae strains did not produce probably very aromatic wines as ethyl acetate does not evolve fruity and floral odours, contrary to ethyl esters of fatty acids and acetate ester of higher alcohols (Lema et al., 1996). The relative amounts of total carbonyl compounds found in the experimental wines produced by “Southern” yeasts were lower than the amounts determined in wines obtained by “Northern” yeasts. In particular, total carbonyl compounds ranged from 0.1% to 1.3% and from 0.1% to 0.4% in wine samples produced by S. cerevisiae “Southern” and “Northern” strains, respectively (Table 1). Acetaldehyde was produced by 35% of “Southern” and 25% of “Northern” yeasts (Fig. 1). Decanal was formed by 45% of “Southern” yeasts, while “Northern” yeasts didn't form this compound. As regards ketones, 2-heptanone and 2-nonanone were recovered in 45% and in 35% of wine samples produced by “Southern” Italy strains, respectively, and in 37.5% and in 25% of wine samples obtained with “Northern” yeasts, respectively (Fig. 1).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, sulfur dioxide is not directly mentioned, but carbonyl compounds, including acetaldehyde and ketones, are discussed in relation to the production of wines by different S. cerevisiae strains. While sulfur dioxide is commonly used in winemaking for its preservative and antioxidant properties, the relationship with carbonyl compounds is not explicitly detailed in the provided text, indicating a lack of direct interaction or relevance between the two terms in this specific context.
